title: Delta endstop mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Endstop mount for a Delta using these metal corners: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Colorful-all-metal-3D-Kossel-printer-2020-aluminum-alloy-delta-angle-corner-kit-Kossel-corner-kit/32787024606.html

I'm upgrading my Zonestar D810 using 2020 metal corners bought from AliExpress. I'm still mounting the motors on the top of the printer, and need somewhere to mount the endstops. I want these to be adjustable as well... that's still a WIP. Probably this will work OK with other Kossel-based deltas using these metal corners.

Use an M4 screw and nut to attach to the existing hole in the corner piece.
Use 4gx12mm countersunk woodscrews to attach endstop to mount. Self-tapping screws as supplied with the kit are probably OK, but they don't fit tightly into the endstop holes.

I removed the metal levers from the endstops, partly because they fell off, partly because I think it's more accurate without those levers and their sloppy axles. This will still work with the levers if you want to keep them.

I've temporarily hotglued some M3x35 screws to the carriages so that the head presses the button on the endstop. Future plan is for the M3 adjustment screw to be designed into the carriage.

[Edit 9 Oct 17]: The hot-glued screws work surprisingly well :) But I have now designed and printed one carriage with the screw mount.

title: VEX Robotics Match Controller and Raspberry Pi Case

description.text:
SEE THE LATEST VERSION HERE
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2749903

UPDATE: V2.0 - 10-7-17

  • fixed part 2 tolerating on the pi mounting points
  • fixed alignment of part 2 with the pi I/O ports
  • fixed plastic thickness on part 2 for the attachment of part 3

Raspberry pi 3 and vex robotics match controller mount to attach to the back of the vex field monitor stand or standard 100 x 100 mm vesa screen mount.

Part 1 and 2 are the components that make up the case

Part 3 (optional) is just a field identification tag that could be customized per event, a few options are provided.

REQUIRED HARDWARE:

  • 4x 8-32 x 7/8" socket head cap screws (attach case top and bottom shells)
  • 2x 8-32 x 1/4" optional mounting hardware for part 3
  • 4x 4-48 x 1/4" socket head cap screws (attach pi to case)
  • 4x M4 x 0.7 x 8 mm socket head cap screws (attachment to vesa mount or field monitor bracket)

Standard 8-32" VEX screws can be used to assemble the case.

I believe a M4 socket head cap screw could replace the 8-32 machine screws, however I have not personally tried that.

ASSEMBLY:

  • part 2 should have 4 clearance holes for 8-32 screws

  • part 1 should have 4 interference fit holes for 8-32 screws to thread in

  • the 8-32" x 7/8" screws should slide though part 2 and through the vex match controller and thread into part 1 joining the top and bottom half's of the case together (see pictures)

title: NVIDIA Tesla P4 blower fan adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter for attaching a 75x75x30mm blower fan directly to an NVIDIA Tesla P4 card, allowing installation into a PC or workstation. The pieces fit snugly with a locking tab on the graphics card and friction fit to the blower fan.

Please note that this adapter is NOT endorsed for condoned by NVIDIA, use at your own risk.

The fan shown in the picture, to which the fan interface is designed is:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00B2ARV22
This is a 12v fan, which I connect via a cut down SATA power extension cable:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01IBA3T94

The fan is a bit of an overkill for cooling a 75W P4 card, so I've found that a 50Ω, 0.5W resistor (implemented as 2x 100Ω 0.25W resistors in parallel) in series to the fan slows it down to a reasonable level, though I wouldn't call it silent. Using this solution, the highest temperature I've seen reported from the card under stress testing is 73°C. Based on the thermal specs of the big-brother P100 card, which a maximum temperature of 80°C, this seems sufficient.

Note that the thickness of the chosen fan and centering of the fan on the card infringes on the space available to adjacent cards. Standard length cards fit well in either above or below adjacent slot, but longer, full thickness cards would be a problem. Multiple P4 cards should fit with a slot in-between. Perhaps top/bottom offset adapters could allow adjacent installations, or a 15mm thick blower (at higher speed) could allow a more dense configuration. Re-design left as an exercise to the reader.

description.text:
For your education and entertainment, here's a rubber band powered submarine that's easy to assemble and might even teach kids a couple things about buoyancy and marine engineering.

You'll need to print two other (really awesome) models for this:

  • Propeller, a terrific marine-style propeller which works great and doesn't need supports

  • The amazing 608 Bearing, which is all-plastic (and thus won't rust or contaminate the water with grease)

To assemble:

  • Print one of each part (hull, nose, aft and driveshaft).
  • Glue the propeller halves onto the driveshaft - make sure the propeller is facing the correct way, with the curved edges of the props toward the hull. The propeller halves should be flush against the cone at the end of the driveshaft.
  • Assemble the 608 bearing and glue it into the aft section - make sure you press it all the way down into the cavity for it.
  • Insert the driveshaft into the bearing until it stops.
  • Loop a paperclip through the hole in the end of the driveshaft (this might be tricky, needle nose pliers may help).
  • Hook one end of a rubber band (or rubber band chain) onto the paperclip, threading it through the main hull, and screw the aft section onto the hull, Loop the other end of the band onto the hook inside the nose section, and screw the nose section onto the hull.

Flood the submarine with water, wind it up, and watch it go!

Tips:

  • Get all the air out of the submarine's compartment before using it.

  • You can add ballast to the sub to make it neutrally buoyant by putting M8 washers on the threaded rods inside the hull, and securing them with M8 bolts (which you could create and print yourself). Distributing the washers correctly between the fore and aft rods will balance the sub.

  • Winding up the sub is really easy: just run it backwards in the water, and let the water wind it. This is surprisingly efficient, so be careful not to over-wind and break the rubber band.

  • You can store extra bands in the sub's compartment.

Please note that I'm still refining this thing; it's been pool-tested but could be better, especially with regards to neutral buoyancy.

description.text: This is a large simple hex wrench.  While rebuilding my toilet I found that I needed to remove a 3" nut but I did not have a wrench that big.  Instead of running out to Lowes buying a wrench I laser cut one out of plywood that did the job perfectly!

The attached files make a wrench for a but that measures 3" from flat to flat (as opposed to tip to tip). The .hpgl is for device with 1000dpi. If you need a wrench of a different size, edit the width_f2f variable in the .scad file and re-export the dxf!
  • edit the .scad file in openscad
  • export as dxf
  • import dxf file into inkscape and scale by .0254 while importing.
  • edit if necessary
  • export as .hpgl and send it over to your trusty laser cutter!
    • I made two of these while fixing my toilets. One was 3" and one was 2.5", both cut out of 1/4" plywood. They stood up to quite a bit of force to get the nuts free. I have to say that I was skeptical that the wood would hold up.

This is a stand for a generic 12v peristaltic pump (available from many vendors). The particular peristaltic pump used and fitted to this case is this one.

Bill of Materials/Required Hardware:

  • 2x M2.5x16 Socket Cap Screw (source: Trimcraft RC)

  • 2x M2.5 Nylon Lock Nuts (source: Trimcraft RC)

For best success, dry fit the bolts+nylocks to ream the holes out prior to installing the pump, as printer tolerances may be quite different from machine to machine.

If available, small zip ties may also work fairly well.

Bertillon calipers as used in surgery, biology, art and anywhere where measurements of cross-sections or diameters of 3D-bodies cannot be taken by ruler or tape measure.

The scale is metric (cm), but I found it near impossible to get it accurate within the angular resolution of Fusion 360 and the tolerances of my printer. Therefore I provided a second version with the scale left blank for anyone to calibrate as needed (measure against a ruler and mark the scale with a pencil or sharpie). The construction should allow for an accuracy around 0.5cm, but do not use too much pressure, the measuring tips are quite flexible in PLA (real Bertillon calipers are made of surgical steel which can be sterilized, or at least of brass).

This thing is quite large and allows for measurements up to (and slightly over) 40cm, so I needed to place it diagonally on my 30x30cm printbed. Yet the calipers should allow for easy scaling, though I made the tolerances in the hinge quite narrow. Resizing shouldn't affect the scale, because the relations in an isosceles triangle are independent of the size.

Enjoy!

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

If you print it with the scale on, go to 40mm/s or below for the minute detail. All in all it's not a very challenging print, so feel free to go to 60mm/s and above, whatever your machine can handle.
I advise against rafts or brims, the surface area is quite large and stuck well on my heated bed.
Try an infill above 25% for further stability, it is direly needed.
I have no ABS or nylon at hand, which would be more stable, but look at this thing, it has more warp capacity than the Enterprise :). I need a better insulation below the bed...
Oh, speaking of heated beds, leave the print stuck there until it is cooled to room temperature, otherwise youll permanently bend the tips out of whack when you pry it off while it is still warm.

Assembly

Should be self-explaining.
Insert the scale into it's guide before you align the hinge. Tolerances are quite narrow, but it allows for a nice wiggle-free operation.
Secure the hinge with a short M5 screw or whatever fits the hole. Don't forget washers. A winged nut is perfect for adjusting friction or locking a measurement for transfer.

title: Lego Shortstop/COP .357
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
/!\ WARNINGS FOR STUPID/LITIGIOUS PEOPLE: Rubber band gun intended for recreational purposes. Do not use in public. Wear eye protection. If shooting someone with rubber band guns, make sure they are sufficiently protected. I am not liable for any damages resulting from improper use of this rubber band gun. /!\

Having played TF2 for the last couple of months, I decided to have a go at creating my current favourite Scout primary, the Shortstop. I had to exclude the hammer at the rear because it would interfere with the rubber bands, unintentionally making my Lego Shortstop look more like its real-life counterpart, the COP .357 (also seen in the trigger guard). Due to space constraints, I was only able to include 2 functioning "barrels". It more than makes up for it with its firepower; while not the best in the world, it's still the greatest of any RBG I've built.

STATS
Fire mode: single-shot
Action: Linkage connected to retracting hook
Capacity: 2-3 rounds per barrel
Ammo: Size 18 rubber bands

FEATURES
Shoots up to 8 metres
Belt clip on trigger guard eliminates the need for a holster
Skeletal build reduces weight

TIPS

  • For help with springing the triggers, see the second image. Tweezers may be needed to affix the anti-jam rubber band (a small or doubled-up one).
  • When loading, make sure the rubber bands do not find their way into the notches at the end of the 3M pins. The force of the rubber bands is enough to pry the end outwards, giving the pin a "frayed rope" appearance.
  • The small rubber band connected to both trigger linkages is intended to pull the hooks together to avert jamming. If jams still occur, use a smaller or more doubled-up rubber band.

author: 3dprintingkid5828

description.text:
This is a derivative of the PanelMax Prusa - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21135 by TommyC. It adds a couple of small pots for LCD brightness and contrast, along with changing the size of the reset switch to small and low profile. Quick video of it in action here:
http://youtu.be/6dPR84LiO9Y The click encoder, pots and reset switch are mounted on a breadboard within the enclosure which has expanded to fit them. As the name suggests it was primarily designed for Sanguinololu - it moves the SDSL card reader: www.reprap.org/wiki/SDSL from the ISP and top of the expansion header into the case and uses every other free pin on the expansion header. Having recently built a Mendel 90: http://reprap.org/wiki/Mendel90 I am a convert to ribbon cables so this design uses a single 22 way ribbon cable from the expansion header+isp header to the enclosure. Obviously you can use a different connectors on the end to connect it like the PanelMax to RAMPS or other electronics. Update - works with Printrboard, see: http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2012/07/panelolu-with-printrboard.html for details Check out http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2012/06/panelolu-in-depth.html for more info Kits available on emaker:
http://www.emakershop.com/browse/listing?os&l=301
and ebay
http://www.ebay.co.uk/sch/i.html?_from=R40&_trksid=m570.l2736&_nkw=reprap+panelolu

Detailed build instructions here:
http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2012/06/panelolu-in-depth.html UPDATE #3 - I have re-uploaded the files after tweaking the hole sizes and the strain relief. I have printed over 20 of these now and feel its time to take off the "work in progress" status UPDATE #2 - Mistake in commenting meant the previous update did not have the hole in the prusa lower mount clamp - scad and stls fixed now. UPDATE - If you downloaded the panelolu.scad or panelolu front_left.stl, I have updated the files due to an error that had the letters reversed and a couple of other problems that are now fixed. The firmware changes required to Marlin to make it work are documented on this blog post:
http://blog.think3dprint3d.com/2012/06/sanguinololu-lcd-and-rotary-encoder.html OpenSCAD file now available. The knob is tommyc's adaptation of this: thingiverse.com/thing:17404

print_settings.Notes:: the tabs that snap into place may need to be moved higher or lower, so you might print a quick test first

title: Box Fan Handle (With And Without Cord Spool)

description.text:
This is a replacement handle for a Walmart box fan. I got my fan 10+ years ago, so no guarantees that it still fits.

I added a spool for the cord as well (the non-spool handle is also included).

Printer:

Creality CR 10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.08

Infill:

30

Notes:

Print it sideways with supports (lines are fine). You don't want the weight of the fan pulling the layers against each other.

30% infill is very solid, you could probably get away with 20-25%.
I did a 1.2mm shell/top/bottom layer. I wouldn't go much thinner than this.

Depending on your fan, it can bend over time where it attaches, so the tabs that snap into place may need to be moved higher or lower, so you might print a quick test first. You might also want to widen the gap for your fingers (just scale the lower part of the hemisphere parts). The .blend file is also included for this reason.

description.text: A loading breech I created in Inventor for a future project. I was inspired by the russian 122 mm M1910 howitzer's breech and sought to create a design that is 3d printer friendly. This is the result, taking into account 3d printer tolerances.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Make sure to tune your slicing settings and level your bed as finely as possible for this to work.

Using

To use the breech, place the male part into the female part on the side with arrows, making sure the vertical lines on both of the parts align. Then, twist in the direction of the arrow.

CAD

First of all, I designed this part in Autodesk Inventor using the thread function and then an addon called CoolOrange thread modeler. Once I applied CoolOrange onto the thread, I then combined all solid bodies in the part (CoolOrange creates a separate body for the thread) and then cut away 2 grooves in the threads. Then, I got rid of all sharp edges using chamfers and the extrude tool since sharp edges usually turn into bulges when 3d printed.

MeshMixer

Then, In MeshMixer, I oriented the part correctly and scaled the receiver by 2%. This 2% accounts for the the tolerance of the 3d printer, allowing for the part to fit correctly after printing without any need for post processing.

remixed_from.title: Portable Hard Drive Case with Snap Lid

title: PCDuino3 Nano Case with Hard drive
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The PCDuino3 Nano and Nano Lite are apparently hard to find stuff for (as well as support!). I could not find a case for the thing nor one that fit my needs of also housing a 2.5" SATA hard drive, which was the reason I bought it. So I made one!

I took the base from ralfselfjord's PCDuino3 Nano Shield and smashed it together with a hard drive enclosure from thankyoucaptainobvious. Then after browsing Thingiverse for hours for inspiration I modeled a lid. I modeled it to mimick the media center look, or a Mac Mini lol.

I don't really have a need/use for the GPIOs on the board so they are not accessible from the current version of the case. I have the Nano Lite which does NOT have an IR on the board, so this current version also does NOT have accessibility for this. I left an opening for an audio cable if used as well as one for the ethernet/usb ports. All the other ports have cutouts in the lid. The SD card is easily accessible as well.

FYI it is a fairly large print: 140.7mm x 186mm x 42mm.9

The screw holes are designed for M3 screws, they should be a tight fit. The hard drive screws in, the PCDuino is a friction fit.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2-0.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The bottom (part where the PCDuino and hard drive go) needs to be printed with supports everywhere to hold the port overhangs. Unless your bridging is fantastic I recommend using supports. The top does not need supports.

I printed my case at 0.3mm layers and it came out a little too snug. Unless your printer is dialed in I would suggest printing the lid at 101%.

author: jhaury

title: 1:24 Scale Powered Bogie Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have in mind a project to create a monster based on the Maisto die cast model Ford Mustang. I will mount it on some railway bogies. The Maisto model scale is 1:24. I used this scale and the Standard Rail gauge to set the size of the bogies. At this scale the standard gauge track is 60mm between the inside edges of the rails. I still have a way to go on that particular project but I felt the bogie set alone would be a useful model for others. The overall dimensions of a single bogie are; 85mm wide, 80mm long, and 25mm high.

The details were designed based on a large number of powered bogies for railcars, and diesel locomotives. I wanted to create a bogie set that looked plausible. I was also keen for the arrangement to give the impression of being an electrical drive.

The models here include the Blender model. I created it in Blender 2.58 and so you will find there are no problems with using this model in any of the 2.5+ versions of Blender.

Extra things you will need are;

  • some Ø4mm rod of some sort.
  • An M4 nut and bolt.

For the axles I use wooden dowel, but anything will do. The axle lengths are about 78mm long. There are also two small stubs of 10-12mm long. I designed in a hinging arrangement of the arms connecting the sub-frame to the axles. This means some distortion in printing the side panels can be tolerated when assembling. You may prefer to ignore the small dowel stubs and hinge arrangement.

The nut needs to be installed in the top cross spar early in the assembly. I would suggest gluing it into the socket.

No support is required. There are some break-off bits on a couple of the motor components.

The filenames include the number of times you will need to print of each bit.

author: BouncyMonkey

description.text: My original phone mount was flimsy and was breaking. I noticed a lot of people made custom mounts for this problem but almost every model I've found attaches to the original antenna. This didn't work for me because I had the antenna mod so I decided to design my own. Just something simple.

Super glue the two parts together. To attach the phone clamp, first, remove it from the original mount by completely removing the tightening nut and the clamp should slip right off. Slide the tightening nut on the 3D printed part, slip on the clamp and tighten.

title: Narrow Gauge Powered Bogie Set

description.text:
This bogie set is designed to be compatible with the model railway gauge I am using for my stop motion mine trolley and mine truck. At this scale the track gauge is 36mm between the inside edges of the rails. These bogie sets will be used in a number of other projects but I felt that as a standalone project they might be useful to others. The overall dimensions of a single bogie are; 62mm wide, 80mm long, and 25mm high. I have a 1:24 scale version of this here. This particular bogie set has been used in this Railbike project.

The details were designed based on a large number of powered bogies for railcars, and diesel locomotives. I wanted to create a bogie set that looked plausible. I was also keen for the arrangement to give the impression of being an electrical drive.

The models here include the Blender model. I created it in Blender 2.58 and so you will find there are no problems with using this model in any of the 2.5+ versions of Blender.

Extra things you will need are;

  • some Ø4mm rod of some sort.
  • An M4 nut and bolt.

For the axles I use wooden dowel, but anything will do. The axle lengths are about 54mm long.

The nut needs to be installed in the top cross spar early in the assembly. I would suggest gluing it into the socket.

No support is required. There are some break-off bits on a couple of the motor components.

The filenames include the number of times you will need to print of each bit.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/8aUpeq163Su

title: GCPlug Open Source Plug'N'Play GameCube HDMI Dongle

description.text:
Update 10/4/17: I included a new version of the plug with dimples to interface with the clips inside the digital port, I have not tested this plug design yet, but I had some requests for it.

I worked with Citrus3000psi on a Plug'N'Play GCVideo dongle for the GameCube using my 3D Printed Digital Port Connector. We set out to make a compact device that is easy to use, and plugs into an unmodified GameCube.

Credit goes to Citrus3000psi for the PCB soldering and testing, its a thing of beauty. I have also attached his pictures from the first working unit.

I also want to give a shout out to Unseen, he provided a custom firmware for this project that enables this project to function. The GCVideo project was all thanks to his wonderful work.

For the PCB you can find a ready to order links for the two PCBs and the firmware file on Citrus3000psi's release post for the project.
https://shmups.system11.org/viewtopic.php?p=1277833#p1277833

Now onto the details about this case.

The GCPlug Plug
It is not an easy print, I was not able to print it with any of my machines, I suggest that you get that part manufactured at a professional shop, it will likely cost a couple of bucks at most to have it printed.
It requires you to salvage pins from a PCI connector (Not a PCIe connector), the current process for this is to use a pair of pliers to remove the pins from the PCI connector and press them into the printed plug. It is a time consuming task.

GCPlug Top and Bottom are now optimized to print on consumer machines, you may still want to get it made at the same shop as your Plug though just to get a really nice finish.

GCPlug Solder Jig is just a jig to help you solder the board to the plug it is a really easy print.

GCPlug Button, just a simple button insert. It provides an external interface to program the GCPlug for IR remote control.

Additional items needed for the GCPlug
4x M2x14mm Screws in tapered flat head style
4x M2 nuts

I have added these to my Shapeways shop, if you want to purchase them from this link I get a little bit of the profits.
https://www.shapeways.com/shops/collingall-mods

comments.text: Is there a design that takes standard HDMI instead of mini?
comments.author: Ichinisan

comments.text: There is not, I don't believe there are plans to add a full sized port. Dan (Citrus3000psi) wanted the footprint for the dongle to be as small as possible. A mini HDMI to full sized HDMI cable is inexpensive usually the same price as a regular one.
comments.author: Ichinisan

The dragon on the front is made to match a pawn from the game. On the back it is slotted to slide on and hold the lid closed.

title: Homeworking & Out of Office signs for computer screen

description.text:
Why

I work in a company which allows homeworking once a week;
But when people don't see me at my desk, they are wondering if I'm off, homeworking, in a meeting, ...
With those simple signs they do know if I'm homeworking (which means they can call me by Skype) or if I'm out of office.

The object

Signs: Those signs are 20cm long and requires ~9 meters of 1.75 filament to be printed (20% infill, should work with less infill);
You can choose to print one of them or both.
Hooks: I did not measure the filament required to print the hooks, but they are very fast to be printed.
Choose the model of hook, depending if you have a recent screen or an old one (thickness of the screen)
2 hooks must be printed.

2-colors printing

If, like me, you don't have a dual-extruder, you will need to change your filament at 2.3mm in your slicer (with cura, use plugin like "Pause at height" or "Change filament" )

author: kozayamax

description.text:
This was designed for 3/4 inch (19mm bearings) but with some simple math it can be scaled to just about any bearing size. I even made a little necklace with 6mm Airsoft BBs with this. (scale to 31% for 6mm).

Instructions:

  1. download and print at least 4 links.
    • Pick the wishbone style (BearingLinks07.stl) or the
    • Normal style (BearingLinks08.stl) or mix them up.
  2. get some 3/4 inch (19mm) bearings. (or scale to the size of bearings you have)
  3. Pop the bearings into the links and assemble into a square.
  4. Optional - Add more links and bearings if you want.

Some common scales:
31% for 6mm bearings/Airsoft BBs
83% for 5/8th inch or 15.85mm bearings
Where Scale = 100*(Measure Size of your Bearing / 19 mm)

*Warning 1: Please do not swing this around - the bearings can be heavy and fly off of the links and hurt someone or something.
**Warning 2: Due to the small parts being a choking hazard, do not use this around babies or toddlers.

This is a simple, yet sturdy camera mount for 2 9g micro servos. It is designed to be used with metal gear micro servos, although it can be used with plastic gear servos as well.

To assemble the mount, you will need to print each of the parts once, with the exception of camera_mount_top_B.stl, which has to be printed twice.

comments.text: I printed this out and the pieces do not fit together.  What servos are you using.  It is very hard to see what is going on from the one picture.
comments.author: peter_piper

comments.text: In the picture, I used plastic gear 9g micro servos (usually marked SG90) beacuse that was all I had at the time. The three supports on camera_mount_bottom are about 3 mm too high for these servos, so I had to pad the servo used for turning. It should work fine with 9g metal gear servos (black plastic cover, usually marked MG90S), since they are about 3 mm taller than the plastic-gear ones.

V1 of a basic mount. If you print it with a raft, the leftover jaggy edges on the bottom bite into the foam nicely and hold. I threaded the camera wire back inside the aircraft to a Y adapter to the battery.

description.text: Simple cable split tube design created while observing another print. Simply presses onto one of the nuts holding the X carriage wheels to the acrylic piece. Designed for 10mm split tubing.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print Speed: 40 mm/s

I saw a beautiful Mosquito Coil holder while I was in Penang, Malaysia and decided to make something vaguely similar. Instead of making it from patterned metal, I generated a Voronoi 'cage' of sorts in Houdini 16, and exported it for assembly in Rhino, and then finally as an STL. Here are all the working files.

FYI: I use the top of a tin can in the middle to catch pieces of the coil as it burns, the screw hole for this is part of the print, and lines up to centrally mount the metal holders that typically come with coils. The feet also have insets to add adhesive rubber pads/feet.

FYI2: If you grab Houdini non-commercial from www.sidefx.com, you can edit the radius of the cage, volume filtering parameters, thickness of the wires etc all procedurally. Enjoy!

Holds a 90Â° joint in place while the glue dries. Meant to be used after you biscuit or peg joint the pieces.

1) Print one of each part.
2) Drill out the holes in both jig parts so a 5/16" rod slides smoothly through.
3) Insert a 5/16" nut into the Nut Lockâ„¢.
4) Insert the Nut Lockâ„¢ into the outer jig piece.
5) Thread a 5/16" rod through the inner jig piece and into the outer jig piece, engaging the rod with the nut in the Nut Lockâ„¢.
6) On the inner end of the rod, add a 5/16" washer, nut, washer, nut. Tighten the nuts together. The outer nut can now be used to tighten the jig.

description.text:
this air rifle pellet has plenty of faces that can be modified in a multitude of ways. modify it until you find the perfect shape for aerodynamics and stopping power. have fun using this to make the next best airgun pellet and dont forget to share your findings! what you see is my take of a hollow point with a tip for better penetration. should this be printed in PLA and cast in lead, this would be good for small game, or large game if you happen to own a .50 cal air rifle.

friendly note, if you are using a spring action or nitro piston air rifle, it's best to cast these prints in lead or another metal as shooting plastic pellets from these types of airguns can do the same damage as dry firing.

PLEASE ENJOY THE SPORT RESPONSIBLY.
on your slicer you will have to scale the X and Y scale differently depending on the caliber of your rifle or pistol. here are some imperial to metric conversions of common calibers.
.177=4.5mm
.20=5mm
.22=5.5mm
.25=6.35mm
.308=7.62mm
.357=9.07mm
.380=9.65mm
.40=10mm
.44=10.9mm
.45=11.43mm
.50=12.7mm
20 gauge=15.6mm
12 gauge=18.5mm

i am not responsible for any accidents as a result of using the included files and information about this thing. again, enjoy the sport responsibly.

No

.1 or lower

Notes:

if you are making plastic pellets, 100 percent infill is best. using a heavier filament is even better. if you plan to plaster cast these into a non ferrous metal, it's best to have 0% infill for a cleaner casting process.

comments.author: lukeconaway

comments.text:
there is a cheap 12v 3A power supply
the black board is a PAM8610 2x15 W board (less than $1)
speakers are 4 ohm 3 Watts 40mm (less than 5$) i should have bought better ones
I put 2 caps 1000µF 15 V in parallel (taken on a dead power supply) you're right : for the noise (it seems you know more than me, I spent some time to understand what was the problem), without the caps, the PAM8610 is not working.
for the led : a 4.7k resistor, and a Led.

description.text:
Update : For printing entirely in ABS use the following file " cube_abs.stl ".

Mise à jour: Pour une impression entièrement en ABS utiliser le fichier suivant " cube_abs.stl ".

3D printing Skateboard

Do you like skating? You're looking for a present for your little sister? Create your own personnalised skateboard.
You don't need a huge printer. 150x150 is enough.
You don't know how to do it? Just get a PLA or ABS coil and have a look on the creation tutorial with Marc DUQUESNOY available here:

  • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=66D_bZIk8Bs

Ride with us!

  • http://www.swissdesigncenter.com/

And to contribute to help my studies:

  • https://www.swissdesignshop.ch/impression-3d/1-skate-de-croisiere.html

You'll need:

  • 1 skateboard grip
  • 1 meter long M8 screw cut in 2 pièces
  • 4 M8 Nylstop nut
  • 2 standard Trucks/axis

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NYPP347B2Z8

Skate en impression 3D

Mordu de glisse ? Tu cherches un cadeau pour ta petite soeur ? Créé ton propre skate customisé.

Pas besoin d'une énorme imprimante. Du 150x150 suffit.

Tu ne sais pas comment t'y prendre ? Equipe toi d'une bobine de PLA ou d'ABS et regarde le tuto création avec Marc DUQUESNOY disponible ici :

  • (voir lien plus haut)

Roulez avec nous !

  • http://www.swissdesigncenter.com/

I can upload STL files of different dimensions on request.

Notes:

You need OpenSCAD and the MCAD library to customize this thing.
You need to print the top and bottom file (they are the same but mirrored).
Make sure that you roughly cut off imperfections for a good fit with your power supply.
Printing took me about 1 hour and 20 minutes. I printed it with PLA.

comments.text: First off thanks for all your incredible work. I've printed out the first set and am really looking forward to making another as a gift. I love the new tiles. Would it be possible to get this new base with the 3mm ball magnets recessed inside the base like you did for the cylindrical magnets? I have a surplus of the 3mm magnets but much prefer the recessed design as I don't have to put cloth on the base to prevent the magnets from falling out on poorly sized holes. I've attempted to make some modifications to the file myself but my design skill is sadly lacking at this point. Either way thanks so much for sharing this. Actually your Catan set was one of the inspirations for me to get my 3d printer.

Power Socket Shoe Top Designed for Custom Energy Metering Smart Socket. I am working on this thing will upload more parts soon

Traditional spool holders need a flat surface to put them or they need to be attached to the printer itself. I didn't want to waste the area of my desk and attach to the printer because of the weight issues. So, I designed a simple filament holder, which needs less filament (it's cheaper than other ones). All you need is a wall to attach it. If you have lots of walls to attach something, but don't have any place on your desk, or on your 3D printer, this is for you.

Note: Usually there shouldn't be any problem about assembly. It fits nicely because I've already designed the locking part a little bit small. If your printer is precise, you may need to wrap a band on the locker just to make it thicker. So it'll fit perfectly well.

title: Spool holder for Prusa I3 Rework 1.5

description.text:
inspired from http://www.prusa3d.com/wp-content/uploads/prusa-i3-175-stl.zip
rewritten from scratch in openscad for Prusa I3 Rework 1.5 for a spool sold by eMotionTech (with 52 mm for the diameter of spool hole).
If your spool has a different hole diameter, you just have to change the Bobine_trou_d variable on line 28 in interne.scad (sorry, most of my identifiers are in french).
the given stl files have little differences with the scad source, I took the risk to correct a few things in the scad files before publishing ( substracting a tolerance of 0.5 mm on the diameter of the spool hole for an easier fit, moving bottom of parts to z=0 and reorganizing the high level module calls for easier use)
When designing I included a housing for a M3.5 x 16 wood screw to rigidify, after printing it seem it's not needed, I left it in case in the future it's needed to put an axis or a piece of string to keep the parts together.
A quick description of the scad files:

  • Support_Bobine_Gauche.scad: the file to use to generate left side(seen from arduino board point of view) of the spool holder Support_Bobine_Gauche.stl
  • Support_Bobine_Droit.scad: the file to use to generate right side of the spool holder Support_Bobine_Droit.stl
  • Conception.scad : the file used to display in OpenScad a view useful when designing the whole thing (I write the scad files in Lazarus source file editor ).
  • interne.scad: the main part of the scad code of the thing.
  • vis_M3_5_x_16.scad : a library to integrate wood screws size M3.5 x 16 in designs
  • M_global.scad: a small general library with shortcuts for translations and rotations and tolerance constant used to ease fittings between pieces printed separately.

description.text:
This is a rail with slide to allow the Optimus Control Box to be mounted to the top plate without the need to screw and unscrew the control box every time.

The slide has a stopper, but no locking mechanism.

You can reuse the original screws to mount the rail to the control box. You need 4 additional M4x15 screws and M4 nuts to mount the slide to the top plate.

The model has been created with OpenSCAD and can be customized. It can probably be used for other purposes as well.

remixed_from.title: Bike light to rack adapter plate

title: Planet Bike Tail Light Mount for Racks

description.text: This is what you want if you need to mount a Planet Bike superflash or other tail light with a similar mounting system to your bicycle. PlanetBike makes great little tail lights and they provide a seat post mount, but if you've got a rack and need a center-mount tail light, that's an extra charge. This uses a standard 6mm hex-head screw, which is what pretty much everything attaches to a bike with. The head is counter-sunk so there is clearance for the light. Totally sourced the light interface bits from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8947 so big thanks to gpvillamil for all that fussy work.

Print it.  You may need to file down a bit to finish it.  The file on my Leatherman was absolutely perfectly sized.  You can mount it with a 6mm screw to any rack mount or anywhere you can use a 6mm screw I guess.  It's pretty secure once it's in there.

comments.text: The front to back measurement of this is about 1.47 meters, side to side is 2.6 meters and its 2.62 meters tall. This bike light clip is the size of a large dog. Its a good design but without serious scaling, which will be hard to do with the precision of the clip rails and tab this is not very useful. Thanks for posting it though, I might be able to pull the shape out and use parts of it.

title: Panasonic Viera 3D Eyewear battery cover w.o. nose wings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Hi, there.

This is a little pet project of mine. A friend has a Panasonic Viera TV, I am frequently forced to use the TV glasses for watching 3D bluray movies.

Since Panasonic seems to hate people with glasses the nose wings of their 3D glasses are not removable. You are forced to use the TY-ER3D5ME / TPCD32601 Glasses with a huge gap between the real and the 3D glasses.

This causes the 3D glasses to sit somewhat on the tip of your nose and the space causes reflections between the glasses.

Luckily the nose wings are part of the battery cover, which allows to replace the cover by wing less version.

Just print the replacement cover and be happy. My nose is :D

Try printing with 0.1mm layer height and without supports. Supports are quite fiddly and should be avoided as this piece is quite detailed and small.

This model may work with other 3D Glasses. However the source file is included, so you may use the file to adapt my cover plate.

comments.author: DeanR

comments.text: Well, i have used the 4040 and mgn20 just because i already have it from my old BIG prusa style's printer. But, i tried the 3030 and i make that test. I take the longest profile in the design (Z for me, 650mm) i put on it 2 corners bracket, 1 per side and tried to twist it, the result was a torsion of 5mm just using my hands. i repeat the test with the 4040 and no twist that time. So i prefer to be sure about the structure considering that 3030 vs 4040 is just 30-35% more in price. For the bracket it cost double the 3030 but you need less brcket on 4040 to have the same stability as the 3030 with all the corners supported by a bracket.

title: The Ultimate Spool Holder for Maker Select Mini

description.text:
Edit: Added an Inset version which lowers the spool holder by about 1.2 cm and thickened the clips. This might help for those who intend to keep the extruder internally mounted. I have not printed this version but it should work fine with a small amount of sanding.

This is a prototype remix of The Ultimate Spool Holder (2047554) by Filamentry. I have a modified one that clips on top of my Maker Select Plus and it made a huge difference in print quality. I decided to remix the TUSH and bring it to the Maker Select Mini.

You'll need to print four of these in order to interlock. You will likely need to print them at a 45 degree angle on the Mini in order to get them to fit (I printed mine on the MS Plus). The spool will sit much higher on the holder and will probably interfere with filament guides. I intend to externally mount the extruder motor and have not designed a specialized guide yet. The thin clips have been addressed in the Inset version but they feel plenty strong to me - I can actually twist the stock steel spool holder with the thin clips. I am leaving both up to let you decide.

title: Bike phone holder (Nexus 5 & others; FreeCAD file included)

description.text:
This is a bike handle bar mount for a cell phone. It was designed with a Google Nexus 5 inside a case in mind, but it may fit a variety of phones.  
The FreeCAD files are also attached, so it can be customized to fit your particular phone.

• Print "Phone holder.stl"
  • Print "Phone holder bottom.stl"
  • Insert the bottom bracket into the slot on the phone holder
    • To mount on the bike, place on the handlebar and secure with 2 zip-ties through the holes (see pictures). Note:
    Some filing/sanding might be required to insert the bottom bracket, depending on how well calibrated your printer is. If desired, dab the tongue on the bottom bracket with a tiny bit of acetone before pressing it in to glue the tongue in place.

I liked what dan_d_builder (thanks for the design Dan) did with replacing the joypad for the Amiga CD32. However, I thought it could go one step further and improve a bit on the stock design.
So I came up with three "improvement" designs.

Pick the one you like and print.
Mine were printed with PLA at 20% infill 0.2mm and came out well. I also made a half dome 6mm width which you can print two of and stick together, to stick on the underside of the joypad prints. I did not test the half dome yet but it should work fine.

Obviously with a bit of cleaning, you should get pretty good results.

I have more ideas for designs (like a mini joystick) but thought some might find that idea odd, so I thought I would start with these 3 for now and see if there is more interest.

I created them using Tinkercad, so I could share them if required.

Unlike some, I quite like the CD32 joypad. :)

Enjoy!

title: Prusa i3 Bear Half Upgrade v1.0

description.text:
/!\ Version 2.0 is out :

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2808408

Prusa i3 Bear Edition v1.0

This is an aluminum frame conversion for the Prusa i3 MK2, MK2s and MK2.5.

Josef PRŮŠA has created numerous of incredible 3D printers and its Prusa i3 MK2/MK2s/MK2.5 is capable of very impressive print quality for a very low price. A huge thanks to him and all its team!

Unfortunately, the frame is the weakest point of the machine. It is very difficult to square, it is not rigid enough on the Z axis and finally the frame might move a bit when you do some maintenance. A very good project has solved those problems by using 3030 extrusion aluminum : Prusa 3030 Haribo Edition.

Why another conversion build?

  • To reduce the number of parts to update from Prusa i3 MK2/MK2s/MK2.5 kit (no need to print a new RAMBo cover nor change any cable, rods or firmware from the original Prusa i3 MK2/MK2s/MK2.5)
  • Use more aluminum and less printed parts to build the frame (3D printed parts can crack if tighten too strongly, they are less reliable, less precise and might cost more)
  • Use Openbuilds hardware:
    • To have a single high quality platform of multitude compatible hardware parts (extrusion, plates, brackets, low profile screws...)
    • V shape gives more possibilities to orientate the printed part (45° angle is more than manageable, with T-Slots you might need to add support)
    • Open source
    • Easy to square and build
    • Worldwide shipping plus several other shops selling these parts
    • Powerful community
    • Easily customizable
  • Limited number of measurements needed during the build phase (and no need for a caliper bigger than 150mm)
  • Fully open source by providing STL files, STEP files and Autodesk Fusion 360 project file

Bill of materials

Here is the list of all needed files : bom.md

Modify original aluminum frame

With this upgrade you will need to drill the original frame of your Prusa i3 MK2, MK2s or MK2.5.

There is a 3D print part to help you place the holes accurately : drilling_helper.stl . You can double check the positions with this PDF : frame_drilling_dimensions.pdf

As you will see in the bill of material, the recommended drill bit is a 5.3mm.

If you break the frame, you can send an email to Prusa support to get a new one. You will find few in the Chinese market as well.

If you have access to a CNC machine, you can get the DXF here : alu_frame.dxf

Getting Openbuilds V-Slots

Online shops

Check here : Openbuilds Stores List

Pre-cut

In the list above you will find indication about pre-cut V-Slots for each shops. If a store in your country does not sell pre-cut V-Slots, try to send an email.

Machine cut

The best way to cut V-Slots is to use a mitre saw with special aluminum blade and lubricant.

Another way is to use a circular saw but you will need a cross-cut sled. As well as for mitre saw, a special aluminum blade and lubricant are necessary.

Hand cut

You can hand cut them accurately using a jig (it just takes more time and effort). I have build one, all details are here : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2596242

Manual and assembly instructions

Available here.

Current status

Finish assembly instructions

Links

  • All project data and sources are available on my github : github.com/gregsaun/prusa_i3_bear_upgrade
  • Openbuilds build page
  • Openbuilds forum page
  • Thingiverse page

Sources

Here are a list of sources I used to build this project :

  • Prusa : http://www.prusa3d.com
  • Prusa 3030 Haribo Edition : https://github.com/PrusaMK2Users/3030_Haribo_Edition
  • Openbuilds : https://www.openbuilds.org

Huge thanks to these projects, without them this project can not exist!

comments.text:
And did you get a good calibration result? The problem I see in this method is that you assume, that the x-axis is absolutely parallel to the frame. That would mean that the z-axis mounts are of the same thickness and that the x-axis parts sitting on the z-axis are of the same dimensions. Not sure if that is the case.
If you tape a needle at the extruder (just temporarily) and lower the extruder until the needle is just 1 mm above the print bed directly above one of the white lines, you can easily see the skew by moving the extruder left and right. And that is the real skew that matters. I hope you could follow my thoughts :-)

These miniature trays were designed to be compatible with rug84's Arcadia Quest core box organizer. (see pictures above, both organizers work GREAT together^^)

title: Double Molle 30mm flashlight holder with magnets

description.text:
YAFH!
Inspired by the design often seen here (too often to mention them all - but thanks for the inspiration) I took to design my own adressing the flaws which I encountered in everyday use. My version has thicker arms which should keep in shape when printed in PLA. I lost a flashlight to a clamp deforming over time. So I got paranoid. The upper Magnets (use 3 10x10x2mm neodymium magnets) keep the flashlight from shifting out, should the clamp soften (the lamp is aluminum, but the magnets get a grip on the batteries). Additionally I put an eyelet on there for a small carabiner. I told you...paranoid :)
Spreading the holder over two molle loops greatly improves stability and creates room for magnets (here: 3 10x10x3mm neodymium magnets). Magnets are awesome!
Either use it as a magnetic holder for the lamp or attach a pocket knife or other tools or keys or screws or...
Due to the overall added sturdiness, even in PLA that thing ist strong. You could run a car over it without breaking it (...the car of course) :)
Taking inspiration from this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:166859 you can design your own onto your lamp, so you can walk around hands-free and shine like Gandalf in Moria.

Enjoy!

UPDATE: slight enhancements include modified clips which makes it easier to remove from molle loops or any other strap this thingy is clamped to without compromising it's hold.
More magnets: enlarged channel for base magnets to fit now the double number of 10x10 square magnets. One can never have enough magnets. Plug for the bigger channel also included in separate file. If you insert the upper magnets behind the flashlight body, use the old "Small Plug" file, the channel did not change.

Keep watching, I will soon include a Fusion 360 file with parametric adoption for flashlight body diameters! Yay!

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30% cubic

Notes:

I printed this in PLA wiht three wall lines and relatively high infill in Cura's cubic pattern, which is more stable against deformation in any direction. Tough thingy.
Prints without support if oriented as given in the .STL, but you know your machine best, so stick with your experience. Remember to go a little slower when printing without support.

Assembly

Print the two plugs for the magnet tunnels, insert yoyur magnets (the upper ones for the lamp are strictly optional - remember: paranoid) and press fit the plugs until the magnets don't rattle anymore (stealth!).

Wait for the night and go outside :)

This is a Test cube by PCROX(I make youtube tutorials and designs), I have made this for everyone to test their printers, calibrate and make a cool little design. This is a 10MM cube that is small enough to not waste filament, but not be to big to be unmanageable to reprint. There is a built in start(Skirt), it is easily removable and should keep your print in 100% intact. I hope that this design helps some! Stick around to see more awesome Designs! This is a STL file, you can now put the file into a program like Slic3r or Cura to make it into a .gcode file to start Printing!

5mm Cube Test 5mm Cube Test
This is a simple design to be just an introduction to 3D printing or 3D programs in general. This is a simple 5 mm by 5mm square that was extruded up 5 mm.

5mm Cube Test 5mm Cube Test
Overall, this is a very small print, but it can really help you in the long run to figure out if your bed is leveled, and if your filament is extruding properly. You can now slice this file in a program like Slic3r or Cura to make it into a 3D Printer compatible file.

Why

My Well MB01 came with a 26mm CW threaded outer barrel, and while adapters to the more common 14mm CCW airsoft flash hiders do exist, they usually cost around 10-15 bucks+ shipping.

Features

  • Pre-modeled threads. The thread pitch on the L96 side isn't perfect, but that does make it fit rather snugly.
  • Fits my MB01, but should also fit the MB08 and other Maruzen clones. Possibly even the MB44 series.

Instructions

  • Print it in PETG with multiple walls, slow speed and little cooling to get the strongest part.
  • No supports required
  • .2mm layer height is just fine.
  • If it doesn't fit, your printer calibration may be off. Try printing it at 99 or 101% scale if this is the case.

Open Source

As always the original design file (fusion360) is included, so feel free to improve it (or learn from it)!

author: damienthierry

description.text:
Why

My Well MB01 came with a 26mm CW threaded outer barrel and, while I have already made an adapter to 14mm CCW, I have to admit "native" flash hiders just look better.

So here's a flash hider that screws directly into the outer barrel. The threads are not modeled to "line up" the flash hider into a horizontal position, so you may want to use an O-ring as a spacer if yours doesn't line up.

Features

  • Pre-modeled threads. The thread pitch isn't perfect, but that does make it fit rather snugly.
  • Fits my MB01, but should also fit the MB08 and other Maruzen clones. Possibly even the MB44 series.

Instructions

  • Print it in PETG with multiple walls and slow speed to get the strongest part.
  • No supports required if printed upside down, but you do need good overhang performance+cooling on your printer.
  • .2mm layer height is fine, but .15 or .10 does look better
  • If it doesn't fit, your printer calibration may be off. Try printing it at 99 or 101% scale if this is the case.

Open Source

As always the original design file (fusion360) is included, so feel free to improve it (or learn from it)!

description.text:
This is the base (RepStrap) design of what will hopefully be full fledged RepRap printer. It's origins where in my desire to throw something together that I could put all of my ANET-A8 spares into good use.

After the first prototype was assembled, I decided to use one of the 8mm smooth rods to ream some 3D sleeve bearings that I designed for my A8 to replace the noisy LM8UU's bearings. I then had an idea...what if I did away with the bearing all together and replaced them with slide rails...The results were outstanding and is one of the features included in this release of the RepRap-8.

With the success of the slide rails on the Y-Axis, I realized that they could work on the other axis's as well. So the adventure begins!

Some project goals:
1) Maintain compatible frame volume with that of the A8 even if build volume needs to be sacrificed. That is, as long as the remaining build volume is sufficient to print all of its own parts.
2) Minimal glue, no screws. Snap-Fit only. Initially the printer is being assembled using screws but the plan is to reduce and hopefully eliminate as many as possible.
3) No guide rods. Going to be replace with 3D printed guide rails.
4) No belts. Going to be replace with herring bone base gear system.
5) No lead screw. Going to be replaced with a worm gear arrangement.
6) Noise levels should be considered but not a deciding factor when compared with the projects other goals.
7) In general, look for ways of replacing all metal items with printable equivalents.
8) Develop a means to measure quality and ensure the existing quality level is maintained. At a minimum, the printer should be able to reproduce it's own parts without generational loss.
9) Parts should be designed so measurements are not required during construction to ensure proper alignment.

I'm working on detailed build plans which I hope to have done soon. Until then I'm uploading an assembly file in STEP format and STL's for your viewing pleasure.

Note though that because some of the design elements are actually mods from my original A8, so parts to this design are posted on their own page. This following will include the link and mention any updates to those parts.

  • X/Y bearings and bearing blocks: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2719391
  • X/Y belt anchoring parts: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2722528
  • Cable Management System: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2783509

=====Update: 20180205
Changes to the following fittings have been made to include "keys". These these keys allow attachments to be made without the need for screws and aid in alignment.

- Motor Mount,Y-Axis
- Rail Support,Y-Axis
- Frame Base Fitting
- Frame Z-Axis Bottom Fitting

=====

More to come....

https://youtu.be/SViP3lse-WQ
https://youtu.be/XT6kvPkSYok

Printer:

ANET-A8 / REPRAP-8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Unless otherwise stated, 0.32mm layer height with 20% infill is how I have printed all of the parts.

Some items are meant to be printed together to ensure they are dimensionally identical which is critical for alignment during construction. The rail carriages (including sliders) should all be printed at the same time. Also, the z-axis motor mounts should be done at the same time.

Any STL which has '_LHS' or '_RHS' requires the opposite hand (mirror image) of the STL to be printed also. Not necessarily printed at the same time.

Eventually I'll release a checklist to make these details easier to manage.

author: damienthierry

description.text:
This is a replacement for a rear tray bracket in a Ford C-Max 2016. The original brackets can get loose sometimes and thus be lost.

short story:

developed from scratch by me, works great, we drilled the part, so the .stl files are untested but should work fine, otherwise please contact me.

instruction:

  • print or drill the 2 pieces
  • put them to the rear tray
  • glue them together
  • done =)

long story:

As a bracket in my car was missing I had the choice of ordering one from united kingdom or trying to draw and print one. As you see I decided for the latter. Fortunately I'm very happy with the result - it works great.

Some improvement steps have been done in the process to make it a real good fit.

As a bracket it consists of 2 pieces that must stick together. There is not much room to add holes for screws so I decided to glue them together and it works perfectly fine.

First I thought of 3d-printing it, but a friend suggested to cnc-mill it which is quicker and the result is quite good. 3D printing should work well too.

I developed the model from scratch. Measuring with a caliper rule and drawing in rhino.

they are all 8x15x24/45 or 12x21x30/57 standard LM*UUs

2 inner design.

all credit to their oringal designer !!!!!!!!!!!! gtg to sleep school in 3 hours lol
